rdf:Description.dct:title: Physical reasoning is the missing link between action goals and kinematics: A comment on “An active inference model of hierarchical action understanding, learning, and imitation” by Proietti et al.
rdf:Description.dct:creator: Jason Fischer

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: A) Observed action in progress. B) A possible goal of the action (trapping a fly) based on a potential physical outcome of the configuration (creating a closed container).

ja:simple-head.ce:title: Physical reasoning is the missing link between action goals and kinematics
ja:simple-head.ce:subtitle: A comment on “An active inference model of hierarchical action understanding, learning, and imitation” by Proietti et al.

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD, USA

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: Department of Psychological and Brain Sciences, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD; USA

ce:sections.ce:para: Since the discovery of mirror neurons [1], [2], an accompanying proposal has excited the imaginations of neuroscientists and the public alike: these cells might enable the understanding of others' actions by providing a link to the code for self-generated movements within one's own motor system. This embodied account of action understanding has been hotly debated in the thirty years since its proposal [3–5], and one persistent challenge for the theory is the many-to-many nature of the mapping between possible goals and the movements to achieve them – an observed pattern of movements could correspond to any number of potential goals depending on the particular actor and context. An answer to this challenge has come in the form of a Bayesian inference perspective on the problem [6], and in their paper in the present issue of this journal, Proietti et al. [7] build on the Bayesian approach to provide a detailed active inference model that invites future work to test, elaborate, and fine-tune the ideas. Among the valuable contributions of their paper is the grounding of action understanding in a hierarchical Bayesian framework, a powerful approach for treating cognitive processes as rich compositional models of the world [8]. It is this potential that I focus on in my commentary here, returning to the bridge between action goals and body kinematics: what is the structure of the knowledge that enables our flexible behavior across the vast and diverse array of scenarios we encounter in daily life? I argue that a crucial component of that bridge is a mental model of the physical behavior of the world [9], [10] which allows us to calibrate our own actions and evaluate the actions of others based on their expected physical outcomes. A prediction that follows from this view is that Proietti et al.'s model will yield more robust and generalizable inferences of action goals if it takes as inputs the predicted physical outcomes of observed movements, rather than the kinematics observations themselves. This perspective suggests an alternative account of mirror neuron activity: it reflects the common computational demands of action execution and action understanding for rapid, online physical reasoning.

The environments we encounter in everyday life are never exactly the same twice. We often must decide how to act based on the particulars of the scene at hand – the objects present, how they're shaped and what they weigh, the slipperiness of surfaces, and so on. Likewise, understanding the intention of an action often entails looking to the physical outcomes it will accomplish. For example, say that you're tidying up the kitchen with a friend and you see them pick up a cutting board in one hand and an empty glass in the other. If your friend turns the glass on its side and holds it close to the cutting board as in Fig. 1A, the configuration points to possible future physical states (e.g., closing to form a sealed container), which in turn point to possible goals. Your friend may intend to catch a fly by trapping it in the glass with the cutting board (Fig. 1B), or if the cutting board was chosen for its straight edge, perhaps they'll use it to sweep some crumbs from the counter into the glass. In either case, the physical possibilities suggested by the actions as they unfold provide critical clues to the actor's goals, and they can suggest possible goals that might have otherwise been scarcely considered. The above example illustrates a somewhat uncommon scenario, but in many cases predicting the physical outcome is tantamount to inferring the goal itself, and the actions are referred to accordingly (e.g., we “open the door” or “fold the laundry”). In other cases we must draw more heavily on additional information such as social-affective cues [11], but physical predictions still provide crucial context. Proietti et al. define action understanding as: “...inferring the actor's goal by observing her movement kinematics, such as the positions of her limbs, angles of joints, their relative positions, and respect to objects and the context.” (emphasis mine) Physical prediction incorporates object- and scene context into observations of body kinematics in a way that enriches the available information.

A spate of recent neuroimaging findings support the idea that both action execution and action understanding draw on neural mechanisms for physical reasoning. Brain regions in ventral premotor cortex, postcentral sulcus, and supramarginal gyrus are recruited during a variety of physical inference tasks that do not entail any executed or observed actions [12], and these regions display a striking degree of overlap with the subregions of the action observation network believed to contain mirror neurons [13]. The same brain areas also encode precise information about physical scene structure such as mass [14] and stability [15] outside the context of any action, and multi-unit recordings in the human brain have found that mirror neurons are embedded within a richer population that encodes compositional features of the scene rather than simply mirroring actions [16]. These findings point to an alternate view of the mirror neuron system: its activity reflects the shared computational demands of action understanding and action execution for rapid online prediction of how physical events will unfold in the coming moments. Indeed, a recent study that directly compared the patterns of fMRI response for observed actions vs. observed object interactions found a shared neural code for the two types of events within putative mirror neuron regions, reflecting the structure of physical events without regard to whether an actor was involved [17]. A crucial point is that physical prediction serves as a key input to action understanding and action execution, but it is not the totality of either process – the action goals themselves, along with other key information such as social cues are encoded in other brain areas [18], [19]. Accordingly, damage to the mirror neuron network does not lead to an inability to understand others' actions [20], but there is evidence that such damage does lead to mechanical reasoning impairments [21], [22].

A key insight in the model put forward by Proietti et al. is that systematic eye movements during action observation can serve as a window to the mental processes underlying action understanding. As an initial test of my proposal that those mental processes are built on physical predictions, it will be fruitful for future work to look back at the patterns of fixations measured during action observation. Is the active information gathering process directed toward body and scene elements that will help discern among possible physical outcomes? In some cases this possibility may be hard to disentangle from the salient locations for discerning directly among potential action goals, but recent studies have identified systematic looking patterns that emerge during physical reasoning tasks [23–25]. The outcome of such a test may or may not suggest a refinement of the model proposed by Proietti et al., but either way I applaud the authors for putting forward a well-specified model that drives the field forward by inviting rigorous testing and discourse.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
